page.title: 12UNUSUAL BUTTERFLIES
page.content:
{The White Admiral (Ladoga camilla) was seen in a group of around 20 in a shady part of Hammerpot copse. It is black with white spots and bands. Its caterpillars feed on honeysuckle whilst the adult is seen in June and July feeding on blackberry blossom. It is local, not common and is usually found singly. It is the emblem of the Sussex Trust for Nature Conservation.
{A Purple Emperor (Apatura iris) was seen swooping to a damp patch in Upper Wepham wood with the White Admirals at Hammerpot. It is local, not common and elusive, spending most of the time in the tree tops. It breeds in well established oak woodlands and feeds on sallow and willow. The adult is found in July and August. It is large (wingspan 70 mm) with iridescent purple wings.
